data.title: Terminal find: give some feedback when there are no results
data.body:
1. Terminal, find widget
2. Search for something which has no results
3. The find widget does not give any feedback to the user. Notice how the editor find widget says `no results` in red. I understand we are trying to save space in the terminal find widget but we could still do a red border in the input field

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:

- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 6.1.7601
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
markdown-toc|Ala|1.5.6
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
EditorConfig|Edi|0.10.0
beautify|Hoo|1.1.1
sublime-keybindings|ms-|2.9.1
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.2.1
material-icon-theme|PKi|2.2.0

(1 theme extensions excluded)


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open any file
2. Add some newline to the bottom
3. Save

The newlines has been just added is removed automatically.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions:  Not test yet.

------

Maybe it was caused by some plugin, especially EditorConfig.

Hope the priority of `settings.json` is higher than a plugin, or some configuration to set it.

My settings.json:

```json
...
  "files.encoding": "utf8",
  "files.trimTrailingWhitespace": true,
  "files.insertFinalNewline": true,
...
```

data.title: Fix Shift-Alt-Select to work more like Alt-Select in other programs and Literally every other select function in every program.
data.body:
Right now Shift-Alt-Select is almost a useful feature. The only issue is that you have to click at the start of your selection then input the Unnecessarily long hotkey of Shift-Alt to then click once somewhere else that you want to edit.

The way this feature was implemented feels like a hack because you don't have control over selections or mouse drags or something, But can you please go in and re do this feature. Its the only thing holding VS code back from being a good program that I can recommend and use every day.

Right now the tradeoff is should you go with the program that is slick and sleek at the expense of losing an essential quality of life feature that I've had since I first learned java on Notepad++ a decade ago and that basically every single other code editor has. The answer is obviously that I don't use VS code. Which is a bummer.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Shift-Alt-Select. The feature is 90% implemented.

data.title: introduce "pathMapping" as a more powerful replacement for "remoteRoot/localRoot"

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
Currently the node/chrome debuggers support two models of mapping paths between the backend/runtime and the VS Code workspace:
- Node Debug: "remoteRoot/localRoot" 
- Debugger for Chrome: "pathMapping"

Since the "pathMapping" supports multiple mappings and users are asking for it, we should support this across the board.

/cc @roblourens

data.title: ability to change command and icon in explorer contribution
data.body:
Once a command is defined in the explorer, there is no way to change the icon (as far as I can tell).

``` json
      {
        "command": "dockerExplorer.refreshExplorer",
        "title": "Refresh",
        "category": "Docker",
        "icon": {
          "light": "images/light/refresh.svg",
          "dark": "images/dark/refresh.svg"
        }
      }
```

I may want to change the set of commands or the commands themselves based on a config, state only known to me, or state in the tree itself.  

`when` clause support may be sufficient?

data.title: Fast tasks cause the task output terminal to automatically clear & close in tasks.json version 2.0.0
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->
## System Information:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Debian 9.1 (Stretch)
<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
 - Reproduces without extensions: Yes

**Note:** I've attempted to reproduce this issue on Windows, but have been unable to do so, I'm not sure if it's because executing the command takes longer on Windows or if its because the issue simply isn't present on Windows.

## Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new workspace
1. Create a tasks.json with the following contents (note that it's version 2.0.0)
	```
	{
		// See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
		// for the documentation about the tasks.json format
		"version": "2.0.0",
		"tasks": [
			{
				"taskName": "test",
				"type": "shell",
				"command": "echo hello world; sleep 1",
				"group": {
					"kind": "test",
					"isDefault": true
				}
			}
		]
	}
	```
1. Run the test test several times, note how the terminal remains visible after the task has completed, and contains the following message: 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5873790/30079779-550467f6-924f-11e7-9531-64892f51878b.png)
1. Remove the sleep portion of the command so that the command line of tasks.json reads as follows:
`"command": "echo hello world"`
1. Run the test task several times, note that if you still had the terminal open from the previous step, that it gets automatically closed after the task completes. The terminal re-opens every time the new version of the command is run, and is automatically closed afterwards. The following is all that is printed (note that the "Terminal will be reused by tasks, press any key to close it" message is not displayed)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5873790/30079964-0cba22b4-9250-11e7-931e-7f90ab6d62c3.png)

## Additional Info
This is actually a combination of two parts of the same issue, the first being that in tasks.json version 2.0.0 a task which terminates too quickly will automatically clear and close the tasks output terminal. In tasks.json version 0.1.0, the expected behavior (of the task output terminal remaining open) occurs regardless of whether or not the task completes extremely quickly.

I have also included a [zip archive](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1278719/example.zip) containing two versions of an example workspaces where this problem is present; the workspaces contain the source code for a basic "Hello World" program, a makefile to build it, and the appropriate tasks.json. The `tasks-new` workspace uses tasks.json version 2.0.0 whereas 'tasks-legacy' uses tasks.json version 0.1.0. The behavior I've experienced in these workspaces is as follows:

| Workspace 	| Build Command (In a clean workspace) 	| Build Command (When the program has already been compiled) 	| Test Command 	| Test Command (When the example program has been built with the sleep(1) line enabled) 	|
|--------------	|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------	|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------	|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------	|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------	|
| tasks-legacy 	| Build output is displayed, the terminal remains open 	| "make: Nothing to be done for 'build'." is displayed, the terminal remains open 	| "[0] './bin/a.out'" is displayed, the terminal remains open 	| "[0] './bin/a.out'" is displayed, the terminal remains open 	|
| tasks-new 	| Build output is displayed, the terminal remains open, "Terminal will be reused by tasks, press any key to close it." message is displayed 	| "make: Nothing to be done for 'build'." is displayed, the terminal is closed when the task completes 	| "[0] './bin/a.out'" is displayed, the terminal is closed when the task completes 	| "[0] './bin/a.out'" is displayed, the terminal remains open, "Terminal will be reused by tasks, press any key to close it." message is displayed 	|
|  	|  	|  	|  	|  	|

## Files
[example.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1278719/example.zip)

data.title: Feature request: git.clone command parameter

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I would love to use the `git.clone` command. My UseCase is to fork a github project first (via API) and then clone the fork. For the user this could be just a simple task and he should not mess around with the URLs.

Right now the `git.clone` command does not allow to give an existing URL to clone but always asks for a url to input.

prettify-json|moh|0.0.3

color-highlight|nau|2.3.0
mysql-inline-decorator|odu|0.0.4
polymer-ide|pol|0.6.0
datetime|rid|1.0.5
write-good-linter|tra|0.0.3
bootstrap-3-snippets|wcw|0.1.0
JasmineSnippets|xab|1.0.0
JavaScriptSnippets|xab|1.4.1
vscode-open-in-github|ziy|1.2.7

(3 theme extensions excluded)


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a project.
  1.1 Open a new window on a second screen and drag some files from the said project if need be.
2. CODE!
3. Try to make a commit through built in SC...
4. Enter a comment, but get no response when doing `CTRL` + `ENTER` or menu Commit All.
  4.1 If you can make commit attempt to push changes.
5. Watch nothing happen.
6. Look down to see your time plugin stopped 20 minutes ago.
 6.1 Notice there is no time because you disabled the plugin go to step 9.
7. Reload the window, go to step 3.
  7.1 notice this is the second time you've had to reload the window, proceed to step 8.
8. Disable time plugin.
  8.1 Reload window, Go To step 3.
9. Completely exit code and relaunch, go to step 1.
  9.1 You've done this twice now, go to step 10.
10. Create an issue on GitHub.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: No, not extensivley tested however.

data.title: 2017-09-05. Merged in translations from Transifex.
data.body: Final localization push for 1.16.

data.title: Code helper takes up more than 100% of CPU
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->
Code helper is consuming most of my cpu, per other issues I typed in 'ps aux | grep -i code' and this appeared on the terminal

data.title: [Request] Color Picker support from command palette
data.body:
Add support for launching the color picker from the command palette in any language.


Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open command palette.
2. Option to launch color picker.

data.title: Decorators can conflict with one another
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.16.0-insider (1452d0a8f75cc7be3f8ab735af3a198a0f11aff6, 2017-09-04T20:15:38.808Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.16281
---

I have both **GitLens** and **Import Cost** extensions installed and the decorators added to the end of the line by both seem to conflict as can be seen below.

![decorators](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/641685/30073490-fe4bd614-923b-11e7-97f9-5064b6eaa5c3.gif)

I would have either expected the GitLens decoration to no appear at all (less than ideal imo) or that the GitLens decoration (since it was being added last) would win (and once it was removed it would revert to the previous one). But currently it looks like some properties between the 2 decorators get merged which looks far less than ideal 😄 

Originally reported here: https://github.com/eamodio/vscode-gitlens/issues/131

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: No
